Looking for more control in your handstands? A great place to start is by diminishing the amount of momentum that you use to kick up.

Instead of jumping off of your bottom foot, focus on creating momentum by kicking your top leg up. You will still use some momentum of course (at least until you start working on press-ups), but by taking out the "jump" you will use less momentum and gain more control.

If you are controlled on the way up, then it is easier to find control during your handstand and on the way down as well. Good luck! 😃

I noticed a ton of improvement in my yoga practice, from when I started filming "Yoga Bliss" for The Indonesia Channel and when I finished.

How did this happen? Multiple takes.
When you're filming a show, very often, you have re-do scenes that had sound or camera issues. Because of this, I practiced many poses at least twice as frequently as I normally would.

Before filming, I could jump up into handstand and nail it maybe 3 times in 10 tries. Practicing so much more frequently raised that ratio to 7 in 10 tries.

Practice, practice, practice, more practice, and voila: progress. 😊

First episode of Yoga Bliss airs in 4 days on The Indonesia Channel!

Monday motivation! If you've been following me for awhile, you may remember my story of trying, and failing, to get SCUBA certified.
I couldn't get past the step where I had to take my mask off and put it back on underwater. I'm talking total choking underwater panic attacks. I'm not a big fan of failure, so it didn't sit well with me.
I've been determined for over a year to try again, and succeed, and now I have! Here I am rising above my deep fears and putting them in the past, where they belong. We can now add SCUBA certified diver to my list of titles.
-
Ask yourself: What scares you? Why does it scare you? Find the root of your fear and reframe it from a negative to a positive. Rise above it. Repeat after me: I have learned, I have grown, I am ready.
Control your thoughts and tell yourself a new story. -
HUGE gratitude to @discovery_divers for making me feel so comfortable and confident underwater. If you're ever in Koh Samui and fancy a dive, you now know who to call.

Press-up progress report! Today I had a breakthrough. I'm finally getting really comfortable with "puppy" press-ups.
I could do them before, sometimes, but something has mysteriously clicked and I nailed it every time I tried today.

I've found puppy press-ups to be the best way to start bridging the gap from kicking up to handstand to pressing up to handstand. You can still work with one leg at a time, like kicking up, but without any jump.

I always say with practice and patience come progress. I love practice and progress, but patience is often hard for me. LOL.
Whether I'm patient or not, determination keeps me going. I stick with it, because every time I feel like giving up, I know that there is a breakthrough waiting right around the corner. ✌

How easily are you offended? When you feel offended, what do you do about it?
.
I ask these questions, because as a society, I feel like we're becoming a little too touchy.
.
That's not to say there isn't a ton of offensive stuff going on everyday, because it's all undeniably there, but at the same time it seems that some have started to welcome that feeling of offense, and the temptation towards self-righteousness that often accompanies it.
.
I feel like as soon as we combine self-righteousness with a feeling of offense, it becomes dangerous. In this case we run the risk of allowing ourselves to become offended more often, because when we become offended we also get to feel "right".
.
Feeling "right" does feel good. I get it. However this craving to be "right" is making a lot of us too quick to point out how others are wrong whenever we get the chance.
.
If we continue this way, does being offended not become like crying wolf?
.
Instead of being offended by every little thing that we take personally, can we please take a step back, and save our offense and righteous indignation for situations where it really matters? Each of us must self-regulate, and honestly be our own judge of when this is the case, and when it isn't.
.
Being so easily offended by everything around us doesn't bring us together. It polarizes us, it separates us, it makes us right vs. wrong, it makes us angry, it makes us fight, and it makes us, as a population, easier to control. (Ever heard the phrase "divide and conquer"??)
.
I'm all about social justice and righteous indignation (keyword: righteous, not superfluous), but otherwise, can we please chill out?
.
If you're truly offended about something, then do something about it. Take action, don't just complain. If you're just taking things too personally, instead take a deep breath and try to take things with a grain of salt today. 😉💗
-
📸: @iliscrub

Bound half-moon is one of my yoga pose holy grails. In other words, I fall over pretty much every time I attempt it. Every. Time. Well, almost.

I'm down with falling, because falling is learning, after all. And I know it's not about the poses, but about the practice as a whole....but it still feels good to get lucky and nail, or get close to nailing, poses that we find difficult. To get a glimpse of what's possible.

Today was one of those lucky ones. This is only the 2nd time I've ever gotten my leg up there in bound half-moon without falling over. Times like this remind me to keep practicing.

I'm reminded that practice led me to this lucky successful attempt, and that if I keep going, moments like this will become less about luck and more about skill....but I'll probably have to fall a lot more first, and I'm okay with that.✌️❤️😃

Truth time. I performed a social media fast over the weekend, because I've been having a pretty hard time personally lately, and I felt like I had completely run out of inspiring things to say.

I guess I was thinking of it along the lines of my own version of the famous old adage: if you don't have something positive or inspiring to say, don't say anything at all. So, I didn't for 4 days.

I woke up today wanting to post, but I still felt like I had nothing positive or inspiring to add to the world. That's when it hit me: not everything in life is directly positive and inspiring. And that's okay.

While the world is filled with positive experiences, it is also filled with neutral experiences and sometimes downright sucky experiences too. And that's okay.

Sure, it may not be inspiring in the traditional way to admit to you that right now I'm having a really tough time, and that life isn't looking as rainbowy and unicornish as usual; to tell you I don't have an inspiring quote or story to share with you today and may not tomorrow either; but it doesn't help me or anyone else to hide and be silent until I do.

Sometimes I get so focused on writing about smiling and being happy, that it makes me afraid to share anything else. In this situation, I'm forced to remind myself that vulnerability can be as inspiring, or often more so, than rainbows and unicorns. The reality is that sometimes life is messy, and we have nothing positive to say, but we endure. We keep on truckin' and we keep on keepin' on.

So, in the interest of practicing what I preach, here I am: sad, vulnerable, and potentially uninspiring, but I'm okay with that for now. If life isn't rainbows and unicorns for you right now, oh well. Keep sharing, keep living, keep loving, keep trying, and just keep going. Know that you are not alone in your experience. ❤ To those of you who are having an awesome day, don't let this post get you down. Rock on! 📷: @justinslens

This is it. Today I'm moving out of the house where I've basically lived for the last 2 years with my ex-boyfriend. The final step in closing this last chapter, and the first step in beginning to figure out how the next chapter will look.

Change is scary, but it's also exhilarating and liberating (that's what I need to keep reminding myself). It's hard, and the memories are flowing like tears on a sad face, but I'm grateful. I'm grateful, because as I passively observe the memories of this relationship, and the last 3 years of my life, the happy ones outweighs the sad tenfold.

So many of my relationships have served to teach me what I don't want, but this most recent one has served to teach me what I do want, and I'm grateful for that too.

In moments like this, it's easy to let the fear creep in and take hold. It makes me question whether I'm making the right decision, or whether I will have regret. The fear tells me to stay here and stay in my comfort zone, because if I leave I might fail.

Fear has a function. It keeps us alive and makes us think twice before doing something dangerous, but so much of life is dangerous, so we push through the fear and keep living.

It's true, I might fail, but I also might succeed beyond my wildest dreams. I won't know unless I try, and as Yoda says, "there is not try, there is only do." So I'm doing it. I am moving out. I am changing. I am doing my best. I am learning. I am growing. I am living a completely adventurous, passionate, weird life.

Sometimes it's scary, but even so, I wouldn't have it any other way...and that's what I keep telling myself when the going gets rough. 😉
Goodbye paradise! Thanks @wretreatkohsamui for your generous hospitality and many wonderful experiences. Hope to be back soon! ✌️❤️😃

One of my favorite teachers @baronbaptisteyoga likes to say “If you can feel it, you can heal it.”
.
I’ve always loved this saying, but until today, I’d thought of it from a purely physical perspective. Then this morning I was in a juicy yoga class from @donnyoga, and a lightbulb went on for me: This saying is also true from an emotional perspective.
.
Over the years I’ve become an expert at running away from negative feelings. I’d smoke weed, drink alcohol, and do anything else I could to distract myself from feelings that I didn’t want to feel.
.
If you’ve followed me for awhile, then you know that the past few months were pretty rocky for me. Too many aspects of my life unexpectedly went sideways, until I was left in a state of undeniable and almost constant depression and anxiety.
.
Unlike in the past, this time there were too many things, that actually really mattered, going sideways, and I couldn’t afford to just run away and tune out.
.
This forced me to sit in it, to feel my feelings to their fullest degree. There were days where I felt as if I had forgotten how to be happy, forgotten what that even felt like. I wondered if the clouds would ever lift, and it scared me.
.
Regardless of my fear and discomfort, I sat in it anyway, and it. was. HARD.
.
Gratefully, over the last month and a half, the clouds have been parting, and the sun has started shining again. Forgotten feelings of joy have been bubbling up to the surface more and more frequently.
.
Then today in class, it hit me.
“If you can feel it, you can heal it.”
.
I left class with a spring in my step, and noticed it immediately. I knew that this was the best I’ve felt in months, but the important realization is in how I created this new happiness: I allowed myself to truly feel all of my feelings. Once I felt them, I knew how to heal them, and the work could begin.
.
If you’re feeling down, I’m here to encourage you to sit in it, breath into it, and experience whatever comes up, even if it feels scary.
.
The quickest way, and really the only way out, is always through. So be brave. Go through it, and remember that the sun WILL shine again, and you WILL get through this. 💗
.

Chillin between takes for Yoga Bliss (airing soon on The Indonesia Channel). Every time I turn around in Bali, there's another beautiful sight to see.

Pretty sure I just met my spirit animal... 😉
As I was walking next to the field where this horse was grazing, there was a moment when we made eye contact and instantly connected.
Next thing I knew, she galloped over and stayed right by my side as I passed the entire length of her enclosure.
When I would stop walking, so would she, when I would start again, so would she. We walked together like this for several minutes until I reached the end of the fence.
I've rarely felt so oddly connected to an animal, it was a trippy experience. Almost like we communicated without words.
I always imagined my spirit animal was a white peacock, but I think it might actually be a white horse now... 🦄

How big is your comfort zone? 🔥
I find that the more adventurous I am, the larger my comfort zone grows. The funny thing is, that no matter how large my comfort zone grows, it never gets any easier stepping out of it.
If I’m not mindful as it grows, I find I can get stuck in a rut of not stepping outside of it often enough. I do the things that once seemed scary, and they aren’t anymore, which feels great, but it’s also in these moments that I realize I’m not growing.
I challenge you to join me in not becoming complacent as our comfort zones grow.
I challenge you to join me in stepping out of that comfort and into growth whenever the opportunity presents itself.
Let’s revel together in the fear and possibility of the unknown, until our comfort zones have no more room to grow. Who’s with me!? 🔥

Yesterday I came back from the @Aveda tent to my hotel room, to find that Neila's back legs were no longer working. 😱
I stopped everything and went straight to the emergency vet with her, fearing the worst but hoping for the best.
Before I freak you out too much, don't worry, she's fine. It was a pinched nerve in her neck, and with some downtime and pain meds, she'll be back to normal in no time.
However, before I knew what was wrong with her, I had to leave her at the vet for 8 hours, head back to @wanderlustfest and sit in a state of constant anxiety.
I'm not usually very public with my emotions, especially fear and sadness, but yesterday there was no hiding them. I was a wreck, and pretty much everyone who saw me could tell something was very wrong.
Usually this uncontrollable show of emotion would make me feel uncomfortably vulnerable. I would try to hide it behind closed doors, so no one would see the usually invisible cracks in my very purposefully cultivated exterior demeanor.
My fears and insecurities sometimes tell me that vulnerability can appear as weakness, and should not be shown often....but that's absolutely incorrect. This weekend has shown me that when you are surrounded by the right tribe, vulnerability can be beautiful, and is an essential element of truly connecting with others.
Yesterday I got vulnerable, and was rewarded with the realization that I have many more true friends and people who care for me, than I was giving myself credit for.
When was the last time you got really vulnerable? ⚡️

I read an interesting @huffpost article, and it said that there has been a rise in a new form of facial and body dysmorphia, since the onset of the general public encountering face and body editing filters and apps.
.
What struck me most in the article were the comments from plastic surgeons, who said that where people used to bring in airbrushed celebrity photos for reference, they now bring in photos of themselves with FaceTune, IG or Snapchat filters applied.
.
It raised the question of whether, in this new edited and filtered reality of ours, we are forgetting so much what we actually look like, that we’re surprised (in a bad way) by the unfiltered reflection that we see in the mirror. A new form of “Snapchat Dysmorphia”.
.
Have you ever felt like you’re not enough without a little filtering? Some cat ears, a flowery headband, or the real point: smoother skin, bigger eyes, and fuller lips?
.
I’ll be honest with you: I have. I still sometimes do, and I’m tired of it.
.
I’m experiencing my own cognitive dissonance, where I want to be fully authentic with you here, but also feel a pressure to conform to the beauty expectations of social media, where we are so used to the absence of wrinkles, rolls, cellulite, and any other characteristic that society has deemed unseemly.
.
I intimately understand the drive to post photos I look good in (more likes!), and I’m not opposed to a little FaceTune when the wrong angle makes me look different than I actually am or I have a zit that’s really bothering me, but I’m so tired of the blatant fakeness of so many of the faces and bodies that we see as we scroll.
.
In the past, I wouldn’t have posted this without editing out the natural roll at my waist (unavoidable in this pose), but like I said, I’m tired... and the truth is, I’m starving for more REALITY on this platform.
.
This is only my opinion, and it’s not even fully formed, but I’m curious how you feel about all of this? About all of the the filters, the editing, the airbrushing, the reducing, the enlarging? Do you feel pressure to be a filtered version of yourself? How often?
.
I really want to hear from you, so please comment below. Let’s make this a conversation. 💗
